Answer: The Earth was known to be spheroidal about 2000 years before Galileo, and Eratosthenes had measured its radius in ancient times.Evidence for the shape of the Earth was apparent for instance to sailors, who saw the sails and masts of a ship coming over the horizon before they could see the hull. Sailors also knew that you could see further by going to the top of the mast (which is why ships had crows nests). None of this would be true on a plane, but works very well on a globe.Sailors also knew they could find their latitude using the position of the sun and stars in the sky (longitude would coThe Earth was known to be spheroidal about 2000 years before Galileo, and Eratosthenes had measured its radius in ancient times.Evidence for the shape of the Earth was apparent for instance to sailors, who saw the sails and masts of a ship coming over the horizon before they could see the hull. Sailors also knew that you could see further by going to the top of the mast (which is why ships had crows nests). None of this would be true on a plane, but works very well on a globe.Sailors also knew they could find their latitude using the position of the sun and stars in the sky (longitude would come later when John Harrison invented the chronometer). This also requires a globe Earth.If you can interpret your own observations properly, it doesn’t take any complicated instruments to see that the Earth is a globe.

question: https://www.quora.com/How-did-people-in-olden-days-such-as-Galileo-come-to-the-conclusion-that-the-Earth-was-spherical-without-very-advanced-technology

Answer: By the time of Galileo it had already been known for at least some 900 years that Earth had a spherical shape. Around 240 B.C. a Greek mathematician named Erastothenes measured the circumference of the Earth to an accuracy of some tenth of km. Accordingly he already knew it was spherical. The measurement had the bonus that it confirmed the spherical Earth. He did it by simply knowing the Sun shone down a perpendicular well on the summer solstice in Syene. At the same time he measured the length of the shadow a stick cast in Alexandria, some 800 km from Syene. By calculating or measuring the anBy the time of Galileo it had already been known for at least some 900 years that Earth had a spherical shape. Around 240 B.C. a Greek mathematician named Erastothenes measured the circumference of the Earth to an accuracy of some tenth of km. Accordingly he already knew it was spherical. The measurement had the bonus that it confirmed the spherical Earth. He did it by simply knowing the Sun shone down a perpendicular well on the summer solstice in Syene. At the same time he measured the length of the shadow a stick cast in Alexandria, some 800 km from Syene. By calculating or measuring the angle of the shadow to some 7°, he knew the angle between Syene and Alexandria at the core of Earth also was 7°. Knowing the distance between Syene and Alexandria and also knowing that 360°/7° is 50, he just had to multiply 50 by the distance and he got the circumference of the Earth and also Earth’s radius to some level of acurracy.Actually the philosopher,The historic rumour is that Pythagoras, some 600 B.C. was the first to come up with the hypothesis. But probably fishermen and other people at sea had had that ide long before that?!Erastosthenes method:

Answer: They used their imaginations. Not all early folks thought the Moon and Sun were gods. They knew they were very big, because they moved right along with you, while you can see trees on a mountain moving at a different pace than the mountain even when you are just walking! You know the mountain is BIG, likely big in proportion to its own trees. The Moon and Sun are plainly discernible as circles, and the features of the moon, to a sharp-eyed person, indicate that things go into shadow, just as the features of an orange go into shadow when you move it around in sunlight. The people that hinderedThey used their imaginations. Not all early folks thought the Moon and Sun were gods. They knew they were very big, because they moved right along with you, while you can see trees on a mountain moving at a different pace than the mountain even when you are just walking! You know the mountain is BIG, likely big in proportion to its own trees. The Moon and Sun are plainly discernible as circles, and the features of the moon, to a sharp-eyed person, indicate that things go into shadow, just as the features of an orange go into shadow when you move it around in sunlight. The people that hindered this thinking were peopleThe Greeks (300 BC) knew the world was spherical, and tested a hunch by traveling to different latitudes and checking out the angle of the Sun at precisely measured times each day. No compass? The Sun has three built-in points, the high point of its arc (noon) and the location (which changes each day, except at the equator) at which it rises and sets. And at night, it has a handy antipode - Polaris, which is almost at 90 degrees. So the sun is higher at noon in Egypt than in Venice. Columbus (1492, etc.) had a globe*. Galileo (born 1560 or so) came after.*Lacking modern clocks to figure out longitude, the old boys’ globes tended to be too small, hence Columbus’ error.People have long been fascinated by the fact that ships’ sails appear before the rest of the ship, hinting at a slight curve in the waters. And doubtless you will hear from many others with bits and pieces of how people just knew the earth is round.

Answer: I have noticed in university that many engineering students devote a lot of effort to memorising the correct answers to routine questions. This enables them to perform very rapidly and correctly on examinations. But it can also have the effect of focusing too much on just one way of thinking about a problem, so that when they approach a new problem, there might be a kind of bias in the way they look at it.Physicists are supposed to look at things "from first principles", and they are not trained to memorise answer. This makes it more likely that they will approach things with a more open attitI have noticed in university that many engineering students devote a lot of effort to memorising the correct answers to routine questions. This enables them to perform very rapidly and correctly on examinations. But it can also have the effect of focusing too much on just one way of thinking about a problem, so that when they approach a new problem, there might be a kind of bias in the way they look at it.Physicists are supposed to look at things "from first principles", and they are not trained to memorise answer. This makes it more likely that they will approach things with a more open attitude that is more receptive to possible implications and complexities.Ideally, you would also have experts around who could validate if the proposals of the non-specialising physicist made practical sense; and these would likely be engineering folk.

Answer: The first phone call I ever made on my first phone was to 911.Crazy, right?I was five years old. No, it wasn’t an accident. Yes, it was needed.I didn’t have a fancy smart phone at five- my mother wasn’t one of those moms. It was a shrek phone-Like this. Anyway, since I was enrolled in dance classes and lived in a terrible neighborhood, having some sort of phone was a necessity. We lived next to a jail. Get the picture?Anyway, it was 4 AM. I, being the bubbly birthday girl, was semi awake. I was still half asleep, until I heard my mother (whose room is right next to mine) vomiting and screamingThe first phone call I ever made on my first phone was to 911.Crazy, right?I was five years old. No, it wasn’t an accident. Yes, it was needed.I didn’t have a fancy smart phone at five- my mother wasn’t one of those moms. It was a shrek phone-Like this. Anyway, since I was enrolled in dance classes and lived in a terrible neighborhood, having some sort of phone was a necessity. We lived next to a jail. Get the picture?Anyway, it was 4 AM. I, being the bubbly birthday girl, was semi awake. I was still half asleep, until I heard my mother (whose room is right next to mine) vomiting and screaming.I opened the door without knocking.“Mommy, what’s wrong?” I asked.“Call 911, baby.” Was all she said. Then she went back to vomiting. I saw my little shrek phone on her dresser. I turned it on, and pressed the middle button (911). I don’t really remember the phone call, but I do remember trying to get them into the house was a nightmare- but that’s a story for a different question.But I’m all for kids getting one of those phones young, as young as four. I’m so glad I had one.That phone may have saved my mother’s life.So get them a phone. Not a smart phone, but something simple. Someday it might just save a life.Edit:Thank you all for your upvotes. I believe having a phone is a matter of safety nowadays. There’s been more than one close call where I’m glad I had a phone. Might tell one later.Anyway, thank you for your upvotes and views!
